00018 /**
00019 @page sdk21static_config A Static Configuration Scheme in SDK-2.1 (Experimental)
00020 
00021     - @ref sdk21stcfg_intro
00022     - @ref sdk21stcfg_iface
00023     - @ref sdk21stcfg_file
00024     - @ref sdk21stcfg_ucfgpy
00025 
00026 @section sdk21stcfg_intro 1. Introduction
00027 
00028    The cvmx-ucfg tool allows the OCTEON SDK user to allocate resource
00029    statically. The need for this is partly introduced by the OCTEON
00030    CN68XX.
00031 
00032    The examples in this manual are based on the default hw
00033    configuration in the OCTEON CN68XX simulator.
00034 
00035    Note that this tool is not officially supported.
00036 
00037 
00038 @section sdk21stcfg_iface 2. Interface and port
00039 
00040    The following interfaces are valid for CN68XX
00041 @verbatim
00042     "gmx0"
00043     "gmx1"
00044     "gmx2"
00045     "gmx3"
00046     "gmx4"
00047     "ilk0"
00048     "ilk1"
00049     "npi"
00050     "loop"
00051 @endverbatim
00052 
00053    A port on an interface is uniquely identified by the (interface,
00054    index) pair, where the index's value is in the range of [0, max
00055    number of ports on the interface).
00056 
00057    The max number of ports (<b>max_nport</b>) on an interface is fixed
00058    for npi(32), ilk(8), and loop(8). It is determined by the
00059    interface's mode in the case of the gmx (4 for SGMII and 1 for
00060    XAUI/RXAUI).
00061 
00062    In this manual, we sometimes use <b>physical port</b> to mean a
00063    port on an interface and to differentiate from other ports, e.g.,
00064    the PKO internal port which is also known as the PKO port.
00065 
00066 
00067 @section sdk21stcfg_file 3. The cvmx-ucfg config file
00068 
00069    The user configuration file is a Python source file that defines
00070    one or more of the following entities.
00071 
00072 3.1. cvmx_ucfg_pko_nport{}
00073 
00074    This dictionary maps an interface name to a vector of
00075    <b>pko_nport</b> values for all the ports (from 0 to max_nport). A
00076    pko_nport specifies the number of PKO internal ports assigned to a
00077    physical port.
00078 
00079    cvmx_ucfg_pko_nport{} is optional. If it is defined, it does not
00080    have to include all the interfaces. If an interface is present in
00081    the dictionary, pko_nport values for its ports are assigned
00082    sequentially. For the physical ports not assigned a pko_nport
00083    explicitly, the default value is 1.
00084 
00085    For example,
00086 @verbatim
00087     cvmx_ucfg_pko_nport = {
00088         'gmx3' : [1, 3, 3, 1],
00089     }
00090 @endverbatim
00091    defines that the four physical ports on gmx3 have one, three,
00092    three, and one PKO ports, respectively.
00093 
00094 3.2. cvmx_ucfg_pko_nqueues{}
00095    
00096    This dictionary maps an interface name to a dictionary. The 2nd
00097    dictionary maps the index of a physical port to a vector of numbers
00098    of PKO queues (<b>pko_nqueue</b>) assigned to the port's PKO ports.
00099 
00100    cvmx_ucfg_pko_nqueue{} does not have to be defined. If it is, it
00101    does not have to include all the interfaces. If an interface is
00102    present, the user does not have to assign pko_nqueues for the PKO
00103    ports on each physical port. If a physical port is present,
00104    pko_nqueues are assigned sequentially for the PKO ports of the
00105    physical port. For the PKO ports not explicitly assigned, each is
00106    given one PKO queues.
00107 
00108    For example,
00109 @verbatim
00110     cvmx_ucfg_pko_nqueue = {
00111         'gmx0' : { 0 : [32] },
00112     }
00113 @endverbatim
00114    specifies that the first PKO port on the first port of the gmx0 interface
00115    has 32 queues. Each of the other assigned PKO ports has by default
00116    one PKO queue.
00117 
00118    <b>Note that if cvmx_ucfg_pko_nport and cvmx_ucfg_pko_nqueue
00119    indicate different numbers of PKO ports for a physical port, the
00120    smaller one prevails.</b> This means if the user specifies
00121    pko_nqueues for more PKO ports than assigned to a physical port,
00122    the extra pko_nqueues are ignored.
00123 
00124 
00125 @section sdk21stcfg_ucfgpy 4. cvmx-ucfg.py
00126 
00127    This program parses the config file specified in the environment
00128    variable CVMX_UCFG_FILE and generates the code for customer
00129    configuration to be included in __cvmx_helper_cfg_init(). Here are
00130    the steps.
00131 
00132 @verbatim
00133    1. Specify the configuration in a file using the syntax as defined
00134       above and set the environment variable CVMX_UCFG_FILE to be the
00135       path of this file.
00136 
00137    2. Run cvmx-ucfg.py and redirect the output to 
00138       config/cvmx-helper-cfg-init.c. This is to be included in the
00139       __cvmx_helper_cfg_init() function and therefore subject to the C
00140       preprocessing rules.
00141 
00142    3. Define CVMX_USER_DEFINED_HELPER_CONFIG_INIT in the application's
00143       config/executive-config.h.
00144 
00145 @endverbatim
00146 */
